qas.question: What do USB's implement connections to?
What are the standards called that implement connections to storage devices?

answers.text: the USB mass storage device class (MSC or UMS)

qas.question: What is the process of making a novel device look like a familiar device?
Why is the ability to boot write-locked SD cards with a USB adapter advantageous for?

answers.text: maintaining the integrity and non-corruptible, pristine state of the booting medium.

context: USB implements connections to <a0_0>storage devices<a0_0/> using a set of standards called <a1_0>the USB mass storage device class (MSC or UMS)<a1_0/>. This was at first intended for traditional magnetic and optical drives and has been extended to support flash drives. It has also been extended to support a wide variety of novel devices as many systems can be controlled with the familiar metaphor of file manipulation within directories. The process of making a novel device look like a familiar device is also known as <a2_0>extension<a2_0/>. The ability to boot a write-locked SD card with a USB adapter is particularly advantageous for <a3_0>maintaining the integrity and non-corruptible, pristine state of the booting medium.
